Sheriff Chuck Wright gave results of this year’s Operation Rolling Thunder crackdown during a news conference Friday at USC Upstate. In total, 45 officers from 15 local law enforcement agencies pulled over 1,275 motorists for minor violations ranging from speeding, following too closely, improper lane changing, failing to dim headlights and more. The traffic stops resulted in 28 arrests, according to data provided by the sheriff’s office. “We had a very successful week of Rolling Thunder,” Wright told reporters Friday. “We’ve been doing this ever since I was elected sheriff, and this is a good way to keep people from other states driving through and dropping off drugs, stolen weapons, and all kinds of stuff that we simply don’t need in our neighborhoods.” Inside Look: How SC cops swarm I-85 and I-26, looking for \'bad guys\' He said this operation “makes Spartanburg County a better place to travel through, a better place to live, a better place to work and do business in.” He added, “I will go after this nonsense. They also confiscated 21 vehicles, 19 guns and other property, including a $50,000 Aximum watch, over the same time period. South Carolina law allows police officers to take money and other possessions under civil forfeiture, even if the owners aren’t charged with a crime. That money is then used by police agencies to purchase new technology or vehicles. The intent is to give law enforcement a tool to use against nefarious organizations by grabbing the fruits of their illegal deeds and using the proceeds to fight more crime.
